Subject: Songs
Title: Songs of the Federated States of Micronesia
Songs in vernacular with English translations from Kosrae, Pohnpei, Chuuk and Yap states. The songs are arranged by state from east to west (Kosrae, Pohnpel, Chuuk and Yap). Within each state, the songs are arranged alphabetically. Each song includes pronunciation, translation and a brief description.
DESCRIPTION: This collection contains transcriptions of folk and popular songs from many of the islands in the Federated States of Micronesia. The songs were recorded, translated and proofread by students at the Yap State Campus and the National Campus of the College of Micronesia 2004-2007. All transcriptions were done by Daniel C. Meyer.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: Songs of the Federated States of Micronesia
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: Songs of the Federated States of Micronesia
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF created by iREi (2025). Digitized from the binder courtesy of the COM-FSM Library, with special thanks to librarian Scarlett Lebehn. Scanning conducted by Belinda Welles in Pohnpei in November 2025.

Subject: Self-study materials
Title: Kaselehlia Pohnpei! – Workbook and lab manual
Author: Kinnaman, Sydney G.|Peterson, Ray
The Kaselehlia Pohnpei! workbook and lab manual accompanies the self-access language course prototype module produced at the University of Oregon. The complete module contains this workbook, a video and an audio tape.
DESCRIPTION: Kaselehlia Pohnpei! is a self-directed introduction to Pohnpeian language and culture. It has been specifically developed for technical assistants and anthropology students from the University of Oregon who will be working on a variety of projects on Pohnpei and who want to gain some language and cultural background before they go to Micronesia. The course materials, which include this workbook, an audio cassette and a video tape, are designed for the student to view the video first and then work through the workbook with the accompanying audio tape.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: Yamada Language Centre - Kinnaman and Peterson 1992 - Kaselehlia Pohnpei - Workbook and Lab Manual - Lesson 1
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: Yamada Language Centre - Kinnaman and Peterson 1992 - Kaselehlia Pohnpei - Workbook and Lab Manual - Lesson 1

Subject: Living things and environment
Title: Sapwatailet – Our World
Author: Hayashida, Mio
DESCRIPTION: This book was written for environmental education at ECE level in Pohnpei.
ABSTRACT: The story starts with a tragic incident when a turtle father died from eating a plastic bag by accident. The funeral was held by the friends of the sea and they started talking about what's happening in the sea.... This is a fiction but this is actually happening on the earth and in our ocean. Our islands are getting full of trash. We have to face this situation seriously as persons and also as teachers. We have duty to teach children about this situation and help them get idea of what we should do or what we can do. Teaching about 4Rs (Refuse, Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle) would be a good idea. And also, let's change our own behavior. Show our nurturing, affectionate attitude toward our environment, and from this, children will learn how to take care of our environment in the true sense.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: Pohnpei DOE 2012 Hayashida Mio - Sapwatailet - Our World (Story for environmental education)
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: Pohnpei DOE 2012 Hayashida Mio - Sapwatailet - Our World (Story for environmental education)

Subject: History
Collection: Publications by the FSM Department of Education
Title: Over Seas and Time
Author: Smit, Timothy J.
DESCRIPTION: Over Seas and Time is a textbook about the history of Micronesia, specifically the Federated States of Micronesia. While there are references to Palau, the Marshall Islands, Guam, and the Nothern Marianas, it is only because the history of these places is interconnected. Still, the focus of this textbook lies within the FSM, and will be of most interest to FSM high school students.

Subject: Instructional strategies
Title: National Vernacular Language Arts (VLA) Curriculum
Author: Koh, Ming Wei|Taboroši, Danko, Danko
Contributor / Project / Partner: Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi)|Center for Getting Things Started (C4GTS)
DESCRIPTION: This document is a teacher-oriented resource guide that supports implementation of the FSM National Vernacular Language Arts (VLA) Curriculum across early childhood through secondary levels. It sets out the overarching framework, guiding principles, and pedagogical guidelines that underpin vernacular language teaching and learning in FSM schools. The guide emphasizes culturally responsive practice, respect for local languages and knowledge systems, and alignment with national curriculum standards. It offers practical direction to help teachers plan instruction, assess student learning, and scaffold language development in vernacular and culturally appropriate ways.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: FSM VLA Curriculum - Guide
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: FSM VLA Curriculum - Guide
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): Digital document created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) in 2026.

Subject: Website instructions
Title: National Vernacular Language Arts (VLA) Curriculum – Resource Guide for Teachers
Sub-title: User Guide for the Resource Library
Author: Koh, Ming Wei|Taboroši, Danko, Danko
Contributor / Project / Partner: Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi)|Center for Getting Things Started (C4GTS)
This resource reproduces a section of the National Vernacular Language Arts (VLA) Curriculum, Resource Guide for Teachers (2026) and is included there in identical form as part of the complete document.
DESCRIPTION: This section of the FSM National Vernacular Language Arts (VLA) Teacher’s Guide serves as a user guide for the VLA Resource Library. It explains the purpose and scope of the library as a comprehensive online repository that supports the FSM National Vernacular Language Arts Curriculum. It emphasizes access to a large, curated collection of place-based and vernacular-language educational resources developed across Micronesia. The guide provides clear, step-by-step guidance on how to access the site, search, browse, filter, and sort resources, and understand availability and copyright status. It also outlines how users can view, download, evaluate, annotate, and share resources, highlighting features that support reflective teaching practice and professional collaboration. Together, the section frames the Resource Library as both a practical instructional tool and a growing digital archive that supports culturally grounded teaching and learning.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: FSM VLA Curriculum - Guide - Library
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: FSM VLA Curriculum - Guide - Library
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): Digital document created by Island Research & Education Initiative (iREi) in 2026.

This resource reproduces a section of the National Vernacular Language Arts (VLA) Curriculum, Resource Guide for Teachers (2026) and is included there in identical form as part of the complete document.
DESCRIPTION: This document is a teacher’s toolkit designed to support implementation of the FSM National Vernacular Language Arts (VLA) Curriculum across early childhood through secondary levels. It provides a structured set of ready-to-use templates aligned to VLA standards in listening and speaking, reading, writing, and literature response. The templates are designed to support culturally grounded pedagogy, emphasizing local knowledge, respectful communication, and learning from community members and elders.

Subject: Instructional strategies
Title: Alóllóólen kayé
Author: Yourupi-Sandy, Paulina
DESCRIPTION: This is a draft poster created by Paulina Yourupi-Sandy at Island Reserch & Education Initiative (iREi). The idea behind the “wholesome learning” poster is to show that learning is wholesome and doesn't involve only the head "winimong" but also your roots, your surrounding or people around you, and what's valuable to you.

Subject: Instructional strategies
Title: Fetál alleewen yáár rhóón sukul kayé
Author: Yourupi-Sandy, Paulina
DESCRIPTION: This is a draft poster created by Paulina Yourupi-Sandy at Island Reserch & Education Initiative (iREi). It shows students at the core/top of community and school dialogues/concerns, leaving little room for the two groups to fight amongst themselves. This is accompanied by an opposite poster, which shows the reverse situation where no perpetual learning occurs.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: GEM - Yourupi-Sandy P 2016 FETÁL ALLEEWEN YÁÁR RHÓÓN SUKUUL KAYÉ [No Perpetual Learning]
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: GEM - Yourupi-Sandy P 2016 FETÁL ALLEEWEN YÁÁR RHÓÓN SUKUUL KAYÉ [No Perpetual Learning]
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): Digital document provided by iREi (2025) from the GEM project collection.

Subject: Instructional strategies
Title: Fetálefirhin kayé
Author: Yourupi-Sandy, Paulina
DESCRIPTION: This is a draft poster created by Paulina Yourupi-Sandy at Island Reserch & Education Initiative (iREi). It shows students languishing at the bottom of the triangle, with school and community too far away from each other, and without concern for their students. The arrows indicate that the farther away the two groups are from students, the more likely they are to fight leading to low student achievement or interest in school. This is accompanied by an opposite poster, which shows the reverse situation that encourages the cycle of perpetual learning.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: GEM - Yourupi-Sandy P 2016 FETÁLEFIRHIN KAYÉ [The Cycle of Perpetual Learning]
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: GEM - Yourupi-Sandy P 2016 FETÁLEFIRHIN KAYÉ [The Cycle of Perpetual Learning]
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): Digital document provided by iREi (2025) from the GEM project collection.

Genre: Cultural content books, compilations, and reports
Subject: Legends and oral history
Title: Legends of Kosrae
Other creator1: Waguk, Morris|Waguk, Onosr|Obet, Palikkun|James, Franklin|Sigrah, Palikkun
DESCRIPTION: This book consists of a series of legends collected from a number of people who have great understanding of ancient Kosrae. This book is targeted for English reading at higher elementary school levels, and its contents focus on legendary concepts. It is considered to be the first book composed on the customs, beliefs, sayings or proverbs, and lives of legendary people of ancient Kosrae which is put into a reading series for classroom use. After each story there are also activities which are made to help students' comprehension.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: KDOE - LEGENDS OF KOSRAE
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: KDOE - LEGENDS OF KOSRAE
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): PDF created by iREi (2025). Digitized in Kosrae from a hard copy courtesy of Alister Tolenoa.

Subject: Education theory
Title: The Pohnpeian child – A teacher's resource
Sub-title:
Pwuhk en Serihn Pohnpei – Mehn Sewese Sounpadahk Kan Ong Mehn
Kasukuhl
Author: Cantero, Francisco L.
DESCRIPTION: This is a multicultural education guide produced by the University of Guam to help non-indigenous teachers understand the cultural, social, and linguistic contexts of Yapese children. It combines cultural background, classroom guidance, and extensive English and Yapese language examples to promote culturally responsive teaching and respect for Yapese values and learning styles.

Subject: Numeral classifiers
Title: Se ac Soko
Translated-title: [Learning to count objects in Kosraean language]
Author: Jonas, Sophia
DESCRIPTION: “Se” and “soko” are Kosraean numeral classifiers. Classifier “se” is used when referring to persons, short, or round objects; whereas classifier “soko” is used for animals, long, and moving objects.

Subject: Legends and oral history
Collection: Self-published and commercially-published books and other materials
Title: Lien Apinam
Author: Sound-Kikku, Innocenta
DESCRIPTION: Lien Apinam is a legendary story based on an actual event from Lukunor, Chuuk, in Micronesia. The story teaches the important values and roles that women, men, and children have in their own survival. Lien Apinam, the protagonist, is a girl who channels the spirit of her ancestry to courageously stand in opposition to cultural protocol in order to save her island peoples from the atrocities of invasion and warfare. Her empowering and bold decision making allows readers to learn the power of speaking and standing up for what is right, even in the face of danger and cultural bias.
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: Bess Press - 2025 - Lien Apinam

Subject: Cultural stories
Collection: Self-published and commercially-published books and other materials
Title: Piafe
Author: Sound-Kikku, Innocenta
DESCRIPTION: Piafe, New Land is a story from Chuuk, presented in a bilingual form and retold as it was passed down to author Mama Inno from her grandmother, Mama Nanis, who chanted “Piafe” to her as a child. The story teaches the values of communication and friendship. In this version, the chant has been decorated with a storyline to set the background for those unfamiliar with the islands.
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: Bess Press - 2025 - Piafe - New Land

Subject: Letter recognition
Collection: Self-published and commercially-published books and other materials
Title: Lagoon Chuukese Alphabet
Author: Phillip, Lahaina
DESCRIPTION: This is an alphabet book intended for children who wish to learn the official Lagoon Chuukese alphabet. It features pictures of objects and items that are common in Pacific Island communities. With each alphabet letter, there is a word that begins with the letter and a picture of the item pictured. Please note that this alphabet book does not include the letters and sounds that are used in dialects outside of the Chuuk Lagoon in Micronesia. Also included is a pronunciation guide for those who are learning the alphabet letters for the first time. This book will help readers be able to read and write in the Chuukese language.
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: Phillip Lahaina 2022 Lagoon Chuukese Alphabet

Genre: Cultural content books, compilations, and reports
Subject: Folk tales
Collection: Self-published and commercially-published books and other materials
Title: Chuukese Folklore
Sub-title: Island bedtime stories, legends and fairytales
Author: Obremski, Jennene Christine
DESCRIPTION: Chuukese folklore, bedtime stories and legends that have been passed down orally for generations and have now been translated and adapted by the granddaughter of Matriarch and story teller Rosa Newo. Most endings of Chuukese stories are sad and tragic but she has changed a few endings for the sake of the readers.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: Obremski 2017 Chuukese Folklore
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: Obremski 2017 Chuukese Folklore

Genre: Cultural content books, compilations, and reports
Subject: Humor
Collection: Self-published and commercially-published books and other materials
Title: The Chuukese Book
Author: Nakamura, Rose
DESCRIPTION:
A book about Chuukese related ways, life, culture and stereotype jokes. Learn Chuukese terms translated in English as well as some full on sentences. This book contains no sexually explicit images or texts. Caution:
Not for the humorless.
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: Nakamura 2023 The Chuukese Book

Genre: Cultural content books, compilations, and reports
Subject: History
Collection: Self-published and commercially-published books and other materials
Title: Pohnpei
Author: Sam, Peterson
DESCRIPTION: This book, which is written in the Pohnpeian language, documents some of Pohnpei's disappearing oral traditions and traditional culture. It includes proverbs (lepinkahs), archaic expressions (lepin mahsen), chants (ngihs), legendary tales (soaipoad), and other knowledge (e.g., Pilepilenpwong, Pilerehre) in crucial need of preservation for future generations. This book is for children and adults, on Pohnpei and overseas. It is meant to enhance cultural pride and empower communities.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: Sam P 2018 - Pohnpei, pwuken kadaudok - volume 1
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: Sam P 2018 - Pohnpei, pwuken kadaudok - volume 1
DIGITAL SOURCE (WHERE IS THE PDF FROM): Digital document added to the VLA resource library courtesy of Peterson Sam (2025).

Subject: Self-study materials
Collection: YapSEED language arts dictionaries, resources, and textbooks
Title: English-Yapese Dictionary
Author: Pugram, Leo D.
This dictionary was compiled from the Yapese-English dictionaries that were developed for Yapese students in grades 5-7. The main differences are that this “Peace Corps Training” version includes all words in all three books, and for easier reference, the sequence of words is plain alphabetical (rather than by subject).

Subject: Everyday stories
Title: Áán átin mwáán we pikinik
Author: William, Alvios
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
"Trial version" stamped on covers.
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Chuukese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
ABSTRACT: This booklet is a narrative telling the story of a picnic at South Field. It follows a group of students as they take part in fun activities, face small challenges, and work together as a team. The story is brought to life through engaging illustrations that support the scenes and emotions described. Throughout the narrative, readers see moments of joy, cooperation, and problem-solving. In the end, the story carries a meaningful lesson, highlighting values such as friendship, teamwork, and perseverance.
DOCUMENT FILENAME: PALM - Printed [Trial version] - CHUUKESE - Áán átin mwáán we Pikinik
THUMBNAIL FILENAME: PALM - Printed [Trial version] - CHUUKESE - Áán átin mwáán we Pikinik

Subject: Place and community
Title: Acn sesr un pa Kosrae
Author: Sabino, Johnny
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Kosraean and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
ABSTRACT: This book introduces Kosrae, an island in the Federated States of Micronesia, through a concise description of its geography, culture, local customs, and natural resources. Aimed at young local readers, the book includes simple illustrations that help enhance understanding and is well-suited for anyone interested in learning more about Kosrae.

Subject: Cultural stories
Title: Angaangan non famini
Author: William, Alvios
Publisher: UH Social Science Research Institute (SSRI), University of Hawaii at Manoa
Contributor / Project / Partner: Pacific Area Language Materials Development Center
"Trial version" stamped on covers.
DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Chuukese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
ABSTRACT: This booklet tells the story of Chiro's family life. It explains how Chiro's parents share responsibilities at home. The mother and father each have their own tasks, and Chiro and his two sisters also have their own duties. Chiro’s family life is not only about cleaning the house, farming even cooks together, they also enjoy spending their free time on vacations. This book is suitable for children because it shows an example of an ideal family and teaches good values.

DESCRIPTION: This title is part of the PALM (Pacific Area Languages Materials) collection, a series of literacy and educational resources produced mainly in the 1970s–1990s to support learning in the indigenous languages of Micronesia. While PALM books often feature short narratives or culturally grounded lessons with simple illustrations, the series also includes translated foreign stories—such as fairytales and fables—and a range of non-fiction texts. Written entirely in Chuukese and intended for elementary students, this book supports reading fluency, vocabulary development, and cultural relevance by providing accessible, locally meaningful texts within a structured instructional sequence.
